KhETOx1C7sBsiLl-7VYT7g.text: Dropped in for some dinner last night.  Menu is short and sweet, killer fried chicken and deviled eggs.  Tasty wines and great ambiance make this a place I'll come back to!

Efli2AxDi5ieVjkwDLz1Hw.text: Excellent (unassuming) place. Open late and service is excellent. Great music and food (mac & cheese especially).  Suzanne and Fernando were incredible hosts. Highly recommend!!!!

3lVSnoLAPOWLEtWWzs0Kzw.text: I'm honestly perplexed by this place. The ambiance is great as is the location and I love all the seats at the bar.But the food is shockingly, unbelievably horrible. It is honestly some of the most offensive-tasting crap I've ever had the misfortune of sampling. Let's break it down a bit.I came for a late night meal and asked the bartender what she liked on the menu. She recommended the Chicken Pap, a fried chicken sandwich for 8 pounds. I also ordered chips.Some complimentary popcorn was served to start, but it was cold, stale, and devoid of any hint of salt or butter. Nearly inedible.The chips were the least offensive part of the meal. They were not good and about half were soft, but they were hot and well salted. Decidedly subpar, especially after picking out the properly cooked ones. These chips seemed single-fried rather than properly double fried. The Chicken Bap was about the size of a McChicken and had a few fingers of chicken than promptly fell out when the sandwich was picked up. Worse, it was drowned in a sickeningly sweet spiced ketchup and laced with even sweeter pickles. I made it a few bites and gave up.The bartender convinced me to order the Swiss Burger instead, also 8 pounds. This thing was no larger than the chicken sandwich. The top of the bun was utterly burned black. The burger tasted frozen and was covered in a bright yellow oil slick that had no resemblance to Swiss cheese. It was extremely spicy from jalapeño slices. It tasted like ash, oil, and heat. It was perhaps the worst burger I've ever had in my life, anything from McDonalds would be preferable. I didn't have a drink, only water, and perhaps customers come here for drinks. Burt I honestly cannot imagine anybody eating this food more than once. I'm not very picky at all, and it was shockingly and consistently horrible. Whoever is in charge of the menu should find a new profession.

yEard4NtDRfyqMe0aDbTsw.text: So a couple Americans walked into a tapas place and then realizing it's American after sitting down and looking at the menu... I guess I'm American, having lived in the country for a while now, and intensely familiar with the current contemporary style of food.Yes, I would call this bar and restaurant somewhat American. It has sliders and ribs. But then, it also has truffle toast, salt beef, and tartare, which isn't that common in American cuisine. While the food was decent, I didn't really find any of them especially good. The sliders were probably the closest thing to getting a "yum" out of me. The truffle toast was especially disappointing, as it looked very promising and didn't really taste like anything. The cole slaw that came with the ribs? I could make a better version of that any day.The printed menu did remind me of some of my favourite restaurants in the SF bay area. That was a nice little touch.It's a cute place to hang out at, and always nice to be able to get decent food at a watering hole. But don't bring your American friends here, especially if they are from SF or NY, as it will likely disappoint.

IeqJ6AkdUwGXSA3Cs7v2ow.text: Great little soho spot that is all countered seating and perfect for a pop in with a friend. The portions are definitely smaller than I thought they should be, but the food was good. Go with the eggplant fritters to start and try your hand at a sharing plate. Will definitely be back to try more, the fish was a bit salty for me but this Nola girl must try the po boy. Service was great as well, very welcoming place when staying long with a latte.

photos.caption: Photo of Spuntino - London, United Kingdom. Latte love!

FM5zEWF6_O2BalaYA3ZT-Q.text: Very cool, small little place in London.  I saw this online and decided to check it out.  We had to wait about 20 min to get a seat at the bar (about the only seating) and tried several things.  They also have some great cocktails and desserts, so go hungry.

photos.caption: Photo of Spuntino - London, United Kingdom. Bar area

NO0CV7_KrVWlf6J9N6zxQw.text: Maybe I was overly hangry upon entering, but everything I had the pleasure of tasting at Spuntino was beyond incredible. The asparagus, soft egg & hazelnut salad was the first to arrive, followed by the truffled egg toast and a single pulled pork and pickled apple slider. This was more than enough to satiate me - and everything was chased down by a nice glass of Montepulciano wine. The freshly made popcorn and bourbon tasting flights added a nice eccentric touch to this sliver of a restaurant squeezed into Soho on Rupert Street. Already looking forward to my next visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Spuntino - London, United Kingdom

nUkhPOOEmT2I0Q4XkeYNTA.text: Spuntino's is a little gem in the heart of Soho. I can't understand reviews that say it's not memorable. Everything here is prepared with care and tastes special. The Mac & Cheese is the best I've ever had, creamy and cheesy and then crumbly, crunchy and with burnt cheesy edges, what more could you want? Another personal favourite is the buttermilk fried chicken, so succulent and flavoursome like no other. Great service and heart-warming food. Also not excessively loud so, good for a friendly catch-up. I go back here all the time.

salpsbALcN32ItGzA5V2GQ.text: Being the trendiest new restaurant that appears to have quite fan club here on Yelp, I thought that a counter point was in dire need.  I visited Spuntino shortly after they opened for the day during the week.  There were no other customers in sight and I was apparently their first diner of the day.  Taking my pick of available seats, I was promptly greeted by a member of the staff and offered some chili popcorn a beverage of my choice.  I must state that as an American who has lived for many years in Texas, California and New York I was really looking forward to some American diner style tapas.  Oh boy, was I let down.  While the service was quite good and I ordered only what was recommended to me by two separate bartenders.  The only thing that was American about this place was that the food was greasy, full of fat and salt and quite boring.  Perfect American diner cuisine circa 1950. Round - I started with the truffled egg toast which was a large thick cut piece of white bread covered (and I do mean covered!) with cheddar cheese and a small indentation in the middle which was filled with egg yolk and truffle oil.  At least that was what is was supposed to be. What I got was a slightly toasted piece of bread that was in a puddle of grease from the melted cheese and what appeared to be an egg yolk was a cleverly disguised yellow portion of truffle oil.  Perhaps the cook/chef was a little hung over but I practically gagged on the amount of truffle oil on this thing, absolutely wretched. Round 2 - Next up was the pulled pork slider.  4.50 is a little pricey for such a small amount of food, perhaps you should get 2? Just a suggestion.  The 'pulled pork' - which wasn't really pulled, more like bits of roasted pork - had a brilliant texture and a wonderful flavor.  The combination of the pork and the apple was light and delightful.  That being said, it is not a pulled pork slider.  Pulled pork should be smoked or have a sauce of some sort or just some seasoning.  This had none.  Just pork.  Wonderful pork at that but just pork.  Round 3 - Soft shell crab. DREADFUL!  Absolutely terrible.  This dish had no flavor at all, just grease.  When it arrived it was way too hot to touch which I took as a good sign, at least it was fresh.  Once the crab cooled down enough to eat I tried it first on it's own.  Mistake.  Next I tried it with the provided Tabasco aioli.  It made it barely palatable.  If you regularly enjoy soft shell crab avoid this like the plague.Round 4 - Steak and Eggs.  This was the only saving grace of my entire visit.  A small hangar steak topped with two fried eggs arrived in all their greasy glory.  As I cut the eggs up the lovely yolks ran smoothly down the sides of the tender beef where the juices of both egg and meat mingled to provide a delectable, if not double bypass inducing, moment of bliss.  This dish was made exactly like my grandmother used to make for me when I was a child.    I was surprisingly disappointed when I cleared my plate as if the memory of my childhood was slowly fading as fast as the flavors in my mouth.  The only thing left on plate was the oh-so wonderful juices of the dish.  To which I suggested to a server that they should provide bread lest the wonderful bits go to waste.  Fortunately for me he then pointed out that under the 'sides' section of the menu there lay the holy grail of down south American diner food.  Cheese grits.  Round 5 - Cheese Grits.  Now, everyone in the south has their own way of making grits.  The texture is often debated as are the flavors that people add to them.  It is easily possible to get gourmet grits with foie gras, truffle, etc.  The one thing that almost every grits loving person will tell you is that the should not have the texture of SOUP!!!!!  These grits were TERRRIBLE.  Yea, that's right!  So bad I had to include an extra R!  The texture was thinner than that of potato soup.  Bad, just plain bad.  I attempted to add the runoff from my previous dish hoping the flavors would meld well but alas, once I poured in the juices the grits swallowed them whole like the graboids from Tremors.  Never to be seen or tasted again.  Recap - All that being said, the service was quite good as was the ambiance.  I even remarked that until the server's spoke I almost thought that I was back in local diner in Austin, TX.  I did also have a half of the Mean Time Ale which was very tasty although rather expensive.  I do plan on going back one more time to give it another go but I am not holding my breath.  Why anyone would really want American diner food is beyond me but I think you would be better off going to Ed's.  At least your pocketbook and your arteries would.

XFY0TEtaMzhaDm4_VCghzw.text: there seems to be a trend, ladies and gentlemen. exposed lights, stained tile, no reservations (hell, this place doesnt even have a phone so dont bother even trying), relaxed staff who have lots of personality, yet are effortlessly professional, small plates.i have to copy Tristan J on this one, but really: it felt  a bohemian Barafina - like if Barafina, Polpo, and The Haggerston had a love child. and then named it Spuntino. the popcorn instead of bread when we sat down was i nice touch, prepared by the bartender in the maner of a cocktail - shaker and all. i swear ive had similar stuffed fried olives before somewhere... but i couldnt place it... maybe it just felt instantly nostalgic. The Truffled Egg Toast was a little peice of Heaven... dripping with egg yolk and melted cheese. i was slightly dispointed with the Salt Beef slilder, which was good, but nothing special. but then again its partner in crime - the Beef and Bone Marrow slider - stole the show on that round. lets say my friend started laughing at me when i tried to sweet talk it. it was that good. the beet salad was a bit lack luster. the softshell rab with Tobasco aloli was delish. and then dessert. the bourbon brownie ... you could almost get drunk on it. not too sweet with something a bit chunky/chewy in it... dates? but what blew me away was the Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich. the 'bread' was peanut butter ice cream, with jam in between the 'slices.' it was amazing. i would go back just for that alone. it was a lovely lunch, but im really curious to see how it matures. it felt like it had always been there, but there was room for growth. delicious growth.

eqw4HlO1Gqf0KF84BS7Vjg.text: Really interesting little resto.  Almost no seating areas (its either the bar or one small table) and you'll find some interesting dishes on the menu.  I liked the small and rustic feel of the place but I thought the execution of the dishes could be better.

PUlyMw052zWDsEPectz4jg.text: Spuntino is a trendy spot hidden in Soho and if you don't mind standing in a queue for a while and you are lucky to get a seat you'll not be disappointed. Stilish industrial decor and nice music, it can get a little bit loud as the place is quite small anyway. It's not a place to go if you are more than two I'd say because you are going to sit most likely around the bar on high stools. Food is very, very good and fresh (I loved the mini burgers!!) but maybe to to be honest It's a little bit too priceyThe only thing I didn't like about the experience was eating with 10 people standing in the queue looking and waiting for a sit, it made me a little bit anxious

TKi4cSg4GuvV8c7HOVfrGw.text: Another restaurant under his belt, and another winner. Mr Norman is a man who clearly knows what niches need to be filled in the London food scene, and he does it with a lack of pretension, and quality as a focus.I decided to drop in for an impromptu Saturday lunch, having been in the area and hearing amazing things about it, and I was not disappointed. Having walked by it twice without realising, I finally found the nondescript frontage only by peering in the window carefully to make sure it wasn't a random house of ill-repute. Upon entering, I noted that, as the reviews say, every seat was occupied. However, despite them being this busy, I was attended to by the very helpful bar staff, and was seated the minute a couple left.Perusal of the menu lead to a conclusion; I was stumped. Everything sounded so good, I had trouble keeping within the budget I'd set for myself for the day. I opted for a couple of cocktails, including their Sazerac (charmingly served in a dinky pewter cup) and a Clover Club (another cocktail making a refreshing, fruity resurgence in bars everywhere). Both hit the mark, if a little small in size (though the prices were reasonable, at £7 and £5.50 respectively). For food, I couldn't turn down at least one slider, opting for the pulled pork with pickled apple. It was, quite simply, like someone had taken the best roast pork sandwich and condensed it into a four-bite bun. Meltingly soft, moist (and FLAVOURSOME for a change) pulled pork vied with crunchy apple and little flecks of fatty crackling that mastered both viscerally-pleasant texture and taste. It won't win a Michelin star, but it was amazing comfort food. The same applies to the main dish, a simple combination of spicy sausage (stewed and sliced) with cheddar gritsthis was the only time I've ever seen grits on a menu this side of the Atlantic, and they were pretty damn good, with great texture and full of savoury, cheesey flavour.While the savoury dishes were satisfying, I couldn't resist a little top-up of sucrose, with their brown sugar cheesecake that was, quite simply, the best cheesecake I've had in London (I'm on a quest to find the world's best, so it's nice to see London has a strong contender). The drunken plums it was paired with were very tasty, though as little firmer than I'd have liked. I washed it down with a very fine Blanton's bourbon, which was sadly served in a water glass rather than a tiny cup or rocks glass. Still, it worked well enough, and it's a minor niggle (I work in a bar that stocks tons of antique fancy barware, so I'm probably a little biased).Overall, the experience was a welcoming, comforting one, and I could happily sit there munching and drinking for hours, if only it wasn't bad etiquette in a place this small. I also love the way that the place really does feel like a small, hip joint back on St Marks Place or Prospect Avenue back in NYCI mean it; people have made broad generalisations and repeated what they've heard about it being Lower East Side Chic etc, but I assure you from plenty of experience that they really DO capture that same spirit. I'm sorry in advance if I barge any of you out the way to grab a chair at this awesome little place in future.Thanks to Sean, my waiter/barman/greeter/new friend, he's especially on the ball when it comes to the cocktails.

2v9BlZkEGmEsnJRR9Mb1mg.text: Nicely decorated, but overpriced & nothing much to offer on the menu. Staff with attitude that didn't spare us the oh so loud music. Won't be back, rather go to its elder sister, polpo.

wTcZ6Am2CgNSHiZwrNhIPw.text: I have been a few times in the past. And really liked it. Tried a couple of times recently and had to leave whilst in queue cause the music was too loud. I think I am getting old  :(

wppcwSq8AR-SrxzpkK-8bA.text: I read about Spuntino a couple of times, and finally managed to take a look myself. You really should look it up on the map before you go there, otherwise you likely won't find it. It's a nice little room, that mainly consists of a bar made of metal, you most people sit directly at the bar. The bar feels a bit minimalist, but it is quite practical. I had something that was possibly too small, to be called a burger, but kind of too big, to be called a slider. But whatever you call it, it's just tasty! The fries tasted great as well. I also liked the wine I had with it  I just don't really like to get wine in normal glasses instead of wine glasses, but as this seems to be part of the concept, I'm fine with it. As dessert I opted for a gin and tonic, which didn't disappoint me either. I was there during afternoon; it was full, but I didn't need to queue. So, if you're there at a not so busy hour or if you like to queue, that's definitely a really nice little gem in Soho, that serves one of the best sliderburgerthingy you could find in London.

x0bWVOvW3DqYqRNH3K8CWA.text: We just love this place  our favourite hidden gem of Soho. Trendy without any effort  just love the old style deco. The staff are always very helpful and friendly and the wine list is very good. Always go with staff recommendations but our top choices are The Mac & Cheese, any of the Burgers and it goes without saying the Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich  yum yum ;-)

3CiNl4xzvzdTYcnsH2Efzw.text: [Non-photo Review] For full review, please go to: wp.me/pwXBH-189  SPUNTINO - AN ENGLISHMAN IN NEW YORK (IN LONDON) Summary: The latest, smallest & funkiest Soho outpost from Russell Norman, Spuntino has a great ambience & is a lot of fun. They have concocted some great cocktails and the food is simple, satisfying & just that little bit different for London. It is a great place to drop by for a drink and/or a quick bite, but you could easily find yourself there many hours later, even if you came alone. In search of some comfort I was in London. I was working. It was late. I was alone. I needed food. I wanted comfort. Soho's Rupert Street has traditionally offered a certain brand of 'comfort', although I wasn't in the market for that. Luckily, the same street now offers culinary contentment too, thanks to Russell Norman's third addition to the neighborhood in less than two years. Continuing the Italian language conceit  his first two restaurants are called Polpo and Polpetto  Spuntino is really not very Italian at all, aside from the name and presumably the kitchen's pedigree. Russell described it to me as a diner, although this is diametrically opposed to those shiny aluminum-clad monstrosities that cater to the elderly by day and drunk college students by night, and have at least 30 pages in their menus. No, Spuntino is achingly hip; lower east side (LES) Manhattan hip. It is self-conscious of this fact, yet not in an annoying or condescending way, which is not very LES. Despite the efforts of its raised ceiling, Spuntino is a very small space, and easily gets cramped in the evenings. Ajax, the imposing yet soft-spoken restaurant manager who used to run the bar at sibling Polpo and is the progenitor of the creative speakeasy-inspired cocktail menu, informed me that since they opened the doors, it has pretty much been busy the whole day through (they open at 11am and close 'late'), every day. On my visit, they had been open for about three weeks and he hadn't had a day off yet. Spuntino is essentially one large u-shaped bar, which has a beautiful nickel-like metallic finish. There are 24 stools and a long makeshift corridor along the long side of the 'u' that leads to a small backroom, which has a table that seats six. When they took over the space from a non-noteworthy Indian restaurant, they discovered original tiles buried deep beneath the plaster. These, as well as the extra feet of space they uncovered above the previous ceiling, add considerably to the charm of the room, as do other countless little design details such as the choice of hanging lights. At night, the place is dark, the music is a slightly loud and infatuating collection of mainly American classics, and it is populated by the type of people who tend to know about cool things before others do (present company generally excluded). The staff all seemed to be tattooed somewhere or other, and almost in spite of their appearances also tended to be very professional, especially given that their computer system had broken down on the night of my visit and all the tickets had to be done by hand. As I was dining solo, and as the bar has an even number of stools, I was seated straight away despite the hulking mass of onlookers who were sipping cocktails and waiting for a spot to sit. Score. Bramerican bites As with Polpo and Polpetto, the menus are printed on a stylish thick rectangular piece of paper that serves as your place-mat for the evening. The food is somewhat of a mish-mash of things (sort of like a diner, I guess), but everything sounds appetizing and much of it seems downright naughty if you have any airs about being at all healthy. But this was fine. Given the day I had just had, and the week I was about to, I felt the need, the need for greed. Sazerac cocktail:Before consuming any food, I decided I should try one of their cocktails, which all sounded interesting. My initial tipple was the Sazerac, which was poured from a silver teapot into a beautifully engraved antique silver teacup  cutely in-keeping with the prohibition-era theme. There was no getting around it, the drink was damn strong. In addition to the main ingredients (Sazerac rye whiskey, Peuchaud's Bitters, lemon peel and definitely some kind of sweetener), it apparently contained a splash of Absinthe as well, so I knew this was going to be a walk on the wild side. Though it was strong, it was deftly balanced, and I enjoyed sipping on it  as I would a cup of tea  while perusing the familiar-looking menu that was full of unfamiliar dishes. After ordering, they brought me a mug of complimentary popcorn fresh from the little machine they have behind the bar. It seemed sort of incongruous, but the Absinthe was kicking in, so I really didn't mind. Eggplant Chips & Fennel Yogurt:First up was a dish that perfectly illustrated Spuntino's schizophrenic identity. 'Eggplant' (American for aubergine) 'Chips' (British for fries) and 'Yoghurt' spelled the British way. Despite
